sentences.sentence: “Will you carry this little son of Adam on your back to the mountain-valley I spoke of?”

“What? Now? At once?” said Strawberry—or Fledge, as we must now call him—“Hurrah( 好哇 )! Come on little one, I’ve had things like you on my back before. Long, long ago. When there were green fields; and sugar.”
“What are the two daughters of Eve whispering about?” said Aslan, turning very suddenly on Polly and the Cabby( 马车夫 )’s wife, who had in fact been making friends.
“If you please, sir,” said Queen Helen (for that is what Nellie the cabman( 马车夫 )’s wife now was), “I think the little girl would love to go too, if it weren’t no trouble.”
“What does Fledge say about that?” asked the Lion.
“Oh, I don’t mind two, not when they’re little ones,” said Fledge. “But I hope the Elephant doesn’t want to come as well.”
The Elephant had no such wish, and the new King of Narnia helped both the children up:
that is, he gave Digory a rough heave( 举 ) and set Polly as gently and daintily( 轻手轻脚地 ) on the horse’s back as if she were made of china( 瓷器 ) and might break.
“There they are, Strawberry—Fledge, I should say. This is a rum( 艰难的 ) go.”
“Do not fly too high,” said Aslan. “Do not try to go over the tops of the great ice-mountains.
Look out for the valleys, the green places, and fly through them.
There will always be a way through. And now, begone( 离开 ) with my blessing.”
“Oh Fledge!” said Digory, leaning( 向前倾斜 ) forward to pat( 拍打 ) the Horse’s glossy( 光滑的 ) neck. “This is fun. Hold on to me tight( 紧紧地 ), Polly.”
Next moment the country dropped away( 逐渐远去 ) beneath them,
and whirled( 旋转 ) round as Fledge, like a huge pigeon( 鸽子 ), circled once or twice before setting off on his long westward( 向西的 ) flight.
Looking down, Polly could hardly see the King and the Queen,
and even Aslan himself was only a bright yellow spot on the green grass.
Soon the wind was in their faces and Fledge's wings settled down( 稳定下来 ) to a steady( 平稳的 ) beat.

All Narnia, many-colored with lawns( 草地 ) and rocks and heather( 石楠属植物 ) and different sorts of trees, lay spread out below them, the river winding through it like a ribbon( 丝带 ) of quicksilver( 水银 ).
They could already see over the tops of the low hills which lay northward on their right;
beyond those hills a great moorland( 荒原 ) sloped( 倾斜 ) gently up and up to the horizon( 地平线 ).
On their left the mountains were much higher, but every now and then there was a gap( 裂缝 ) when you could see,
between steep( 挺拔的 ) pine woods, a glimpse( 一瞥 ) of the southern lands that lay beyond them, looking blue and far away.
“That’ll be where Archenland is,” said Polly.
“Yes, but look ahead!” said Digory.

For now a great barrier( 屏障 ) of cliffs( 悬崖 ) rose before them and they were almost dazzled( 目眩的 ) by the sunlight dancing on the great waterfall( 瀑布 ) by which the river roars( 发出巨响 ) and sparkles( 飞溅 ) down into Narnia itself from the high western lands in which it rises.
They were flying so high already that the thunder of those falls could only just be heard as a small, thin( 微弱的 ) sound,
but they were not yet high enough to fly over the top of the cliffs( 悬崖 ).
“We’ll have to do a bit of zig-zagging( 之字形行进 ) here,” said Fledge. “Hold on tight( 紧紧地 ).”
He began flying to and fro( 来回地 ), getting higher at each turn. The air grew colder, and they heard the call of eagles far below them.
“I say, look back! Look behind,” said Polly.
There they could see the whole valley of Narnia stretched( 延伸 ) out to where, just before the eastern horizon( 地平面 ), there was a gleam( 微光 ) of the sea.
And now they were so high that they could see tiny-looking jagged( 高低起伏的 ) mountains appearing beyond the northwest moors( 荒原 ),
and plains of what looked like sand far in the south.
“I wish we had someone to tell us what all those places are,” said Digory.
“I don’t suppose they’re anywhere yet,” said Polly. “I mean, there’s no one there, and nothing happening. The world only began today.”
“No, but people will get there,” said Digory. “And then they’ll have histories, you know.”
“Well, it’s a jolly( 非常 ) good thing they haven’t now,” said Polly. “Because nobody can be made to learn it. Battles and dates and all that rot( 蠢话 ).”
Now they were over the top of the cliffs( 悬崖 ) and in a few minutes the valley land of Narnia had sunk out of sight( 消失不见 ) behind them.
They were flying over a wild country of steep( 陡峭的 ) hills and dark forests, still following the course of the river.
The really big mountains loomed( 耸立 ) ahead.
But the sun was now in the travelers’ eyes and they couldn’t see things very clearly in that direction.
For the sun sank lower and lower till the western sky was all like one great furnace( 熔炉 ) full of melted( 熔化的 ) gold;
and it set at last behind a jagged( 嶙峋的 ) peak( 山峰 ) which stood up against the brightness as sharp( 尖的 ) and flat as if it were cut out of cardboard( 硬纸板 ).
“It’s none too warm up here,” said Polly.
“And my wings are beginning to ache,” said Fledge. "There’s no sign of the valley with a Lake in it, like what Aslan said.
What about coming down and looking out for a decent( 像样的 ) spot to spend the night in? We shan’t reach that place tonight.”
“Yes, and surely it’s about time for supper?” said Digory.
So Fledge came lower and lower.
As they came down nearer to the earth and among the hills, the air grew warmer and after traveling so many hours with nothing to listen to but the beat of Fledge’s wings,
it was nice to hear the homely( 亲切的 ) and earthy( 自然的 ) noises again—the chatter( 潺潺声 ) of the river on its stony bed and the creaking( 嘎吱作响声 ) of trees in the light wind.
A warm, good smell of sun-baked earth and grass and flowers came up to them.
At last Fledge alighted( 飞落 ). Digory rolled off( 翻身下马 ) and helped Polly to dismount( 下马 ). Both were glad to stretch( 伸展 ) their stiff( 僵硬的 ) legs.
The valley in which they had come down was in the heart of the mountains; snowy heights,
one of them looking rose-red in the reflections of the sunset, towered above them.
“I am hungry,” said Digory.
“Well, tuck in( 尽情地吃 ),” said Fledge, taking a big mouthful of grass.
Then he raised his head, still chewing( 嚼 ) and with bits of grass sticking out( 伸出 ) on each side of his mouth like whiskers( 胡须 ), and said,
“Come on, you two. Don't be shy. There’s plenty for us all.”
“But we can’t eat grass,” said Digory.
“Hmm( 嗯 ), hmm( 嗯 ),” said Fledge, speaking with his mouth full. “Well—hmm( 嗯 )—don’t quite know what you’ll do then. Very good grass too.”
Polly and Digory stared at one another in dismay( 沮丧 ).
“Well, I do think someone might have arranged about our meals,” said Digory.
“I’m sure Aslan would have, if you’d asked him,” said Fledge.
“Wouldn’t he know without being asked?” said Polly.
“I’ve no doubt he would,” said the Horse (still with his mouth full). “But I’ve a sort of idea he likes to be asked.”
“But what on earth are we to do?” asked Digory.
“I’m sure I don’t know,” said Fledge. “Unless you try the grass. You might like it better than you think.”
“Oh, don’t be silly,” said Polly, stamping her foot. “Of course humans can’t eat grass, any more than you could eat a mutton chop( 羊排 ).”
“For goodness’ sake don’t talk about chops( 羊排 ) and things,” said Digory. “It only makes it worse.”
Digory said that Polly had better take herself home by ring and get something to eat there;
he couldn’t himself because he had promised to go straight on his message for Aslan,
and, if once he showed up again at home, anything might happen to prevent his getting back.
But Polly said she wouldn’t leave him, and Digory said it was jolly( 非常 ) decent( 相当好的 ) of her.
“I say,” said Polly, “I’ve still got the remains of that bag of toffee( 太妃糖 ) in my jacket. It’ll be better than nothing.”
“A lot better,” said Digory, “but be careful to get your hand into your pocket without touching your ring.”

article_info.previous: Aslan任命马车夫和他的妻子成为纳尼亚王国的第一任国王和王后，并且告知马车夫作为国王的责任。Digory为了弥补自己的过错，答应Aslan去很远的地方摘一个苹果回来。

article_info.share_words: All Narnia, many-colored with lawns and rocks and heather and different sorts of trees, lay spread out below them, the river winding through it like a ribbon of quicksilver.

question.en: What was the horse’s new name?

analysis: 文中提到：“Strawberry-or Fledge, as we must now call him.”由此可知，那匹马的名字改成了Fledge，因此选B。

question.en: In the end,who was going to pick the apple?

analysis: 文中提到“The new king of Narnia helped both the children up: that is, he gave Digory a rough heave and set Polly as gently and daintily on the horse’s back as if she were made of china and may break.”由此可知，是新国王把两个孩子扶上马，这场冒险旅程要由Digroy和Polly一起完成，因此选C。

question.cn: 是谁建议找个地方过夜？
question.en: Who suggested that  they should look for a place to spend the night?

analysis: 文中提到：“And my wings are beginning to arch…What about coming down and looking out for a decent spot to spend the night in? We shan’t reach that place tonight.”由此可知Fledge经过长途飞行，翅膀十分地疼，又加上离目的地还很远，所以建议找个地方过夜，因此选A。
文中提到：“Well, tuck in,” said Fledge, taking a big mouthful of grass.”由此可知Fledge的晚餐是草，因此选A。
